child.pub-comments: Wurms notes that it might be possible to combine the Buin and Nasioi Families together, based on lexical interrelationship "ranging from the high teens to the high twenties." (Wurm 1975: 792)

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: Wurm writes that "the lexical interrelationship between the three family-level members of the West Bougainville Stock is close and it seems quite likely that it may be possible to unite them all into a single family." (Wurm 1975: 795)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Bougainville Island, east of New Britain and New Ireland, at he western end of the Solomon Islands chain, and occupies much of the south-eastern three-quarters of the island.

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: Wurm notes that this language has at least five dialects, but he does not detail them in the paper. (Wurm 1975: 789)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: Wurm writes that this langauge and Taulil are very close, and nearly dialects. (Wurm 1975: 789)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: Wurm writes that this langauge and Butam are very close, and nearly dialects. (Wurm 1975: 789)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Coastal villages and extending inland for a short distance along the Banu River, on the north coast of the western half of New Britain, about half way between Willaumez Peninsula and the western end of New Britain

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Interior of the eastern half of New Britain within the north-eastern section of the West New Britain District, about half-way between the Gazelle and Willaumez Peninsulas

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Small portion of north-western New Ireland

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Interior and extreme eastern portions of New Britain, south of Gazelle Peninsula and north of Jacquinot Bay

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Narrow coastal strip on the southern side of Wide Bay
child.pub-comments: Wurm writes that "[this language] constitutes a link between the two stocks in showing similarities in several pronomial forms with some members of the Yele-Solomons Stock, especially Lavukaleve." (Wurm 1975: 784)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: Wurm writes that this language and Sulka of the New Britian Stock are very closely related, especially in pronomial forms. (Wurm 1975: 784)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Rendova Island in the Georgia Archipelago

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. child.pub-comments: Wurm notes that "the family status of this group is doubtful because of the limited materials available on its members". (Wurm 1975: 787)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Rossel Island in the Louisiade Archipelago, east of the south-eastern extremity of the New Guinea mainland

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Rossel Island, Louisiade Archipelago, Vella Lavella, New Georgia, Rendova, Russel, Savo Islands, British Solomon Islands

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: The Yele-Solomons and New Britain Stocks have been combined due to "considerable typological and structural similarities between members of the two stocks, and far-reaching agreements in the pronoun forms, even though lexical agreements between them are mostly not high." (Wurm 1975: 784)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: Wurm writes that "the languages of the Reef Islands-Santa Cruz Family have been subject to extremely strong Austronesian influence of various kinds, with the result that more than half of their vocabularies is Austronesian, and that quite a few of their pronomial elements and much of their typology and structure have been taken over from Austronesian languages." (Wurms 1975: 797)

child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Santa Cruz Archipelago, east of the Solomon Islands, occupying the greater part of the Reef Islands in the northern part of the Archipelago and the main island of Santa Cruz itself

root.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1975. The East Papuan Phylum in General. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 783-804. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
root.geography: Islands to the north-east and east of the New Guinea mainland, from New Britain and Rossel Island to the Louisiade Archipelago eastwards across the Solomon Islands chain to the Reef Islands-Santa Cruz Archipelago.
